metadata.subject: Trump's Tariffs May Hurt, but Quitting China Is Hard to Do

relationships.description: Runs factory making Bloch ballet shoes
Representative of company that acts as go-between for Western companies and factories
Owner of company making products for Costco and Walmart

analysis.purpose: To analyze the challenges companies face in moving manufacturing from China to other countries due to Trump's tariffs
analysis.significance: Provides insight into global supply chain complexities and the practical limitations of tariff-driven manufacturing relocation

notable_quotes: "Where Cambodia sits now is where China was 25 years ago" - Piet Holten
"People are desperate to get out of China" - Spencer Fung
"Moving out of China is not purely a matter of cost, but of possibility" - Aaron Emigh

blackmail_indicators.description: No evidence of blackmail or coercion in this business analysis article

illegal_activity.description: This is a legitimate news article about business and trade issues, containing no illegal activity

details: New York Times article by Alexandra Stevenson
References to media coverage of trade talks and tariffs

public_knowledge.context: This is a published New York Times article about international trade and manufacturing, clearly intended for public consumption

analysis.summary: This New York Times article examines how President Trump's tariffs on Chinese goods are prompting companies to consider moving manufacturing to countries like Cambodia, but highlights the significant challenges including infrastructure limitations, supply chain dependencies, and logistical hurdles that make China difficult to replace as a manufacturing hub.
